Annotator Metadata.Steps:
1. Use search engine to search for "British Museum search collection" and navigate to the British Museum's collection search webpage.
2. Select "Museum number" as search field and "2012,5015.17" in text box, then run search.
3. Open the page for the single result and note that the description says that this is the shell of an individual of the Nassa gibbosula species.
4. Use search engine to search for "Nassa gibbosula".
5. Note that according to the search result from the World Register of Marine Species website, Nassa gibbosula is not an accepted species name.
6. Open the page for Nassa gibbosula on the World Register of Marine Species website.
7. Scan the page and note that the accepted species name is Tritia gibbosula.
8. Use search engine to search for "Science Advances 2021 Tritia gibbosula".
9. Find that the top result is an article from 2021 in Science Advances titled "Early Middle Stone Age personal ornaments from Bizmoune Cave, Essaouira, Morocco".
10. Scan abstract and note that the article discusses beads made from Tritia gibbosula shells that date to at least 142 thousand years ago, giving a final answer of 142.

### 1. Task outcome (short version):
The article’s abstract states that the shell beads are at least 142 thousand years old.

### 2. Task outcome (extremely detailed version):
The relevant research article, “Early Middle Stone Age personal ornaments from Bizmoune Cave, Essaouira, Morocco” published in Science Advances in 2021, reports on shell beads made from the marine gastropod species Tritia gibbosula – which corresponds to the British Museum object number 2012,5015.17. The abstract includes the key excerpt: "Many of the beads come as deposits dating to ≥142 thousand years, making them the oldest shell beads yet recovered." This excerpt unambiguously states that the beads are at least 142 thousand years old.

### 3. Additional context (if relevant):
The study offers important insights into early symbolic behavior among Homo sapiens in North Africa. By analyzing shell beads made from Tritia gibbosula (previously known as Mediterranean Nassa gibbosula), the research connects the British Museum object to broader discussions on early personal ornamentation and cultural continuity during the Middle Stone Age. The age attribution of 142 thousand years pushes back the timeline for the emergence of such symbolic behavior in the region.

Shell beads from Bizmoune Cave (Morocco) show the early appearance and continuity of symbolic behavior among early Homo sapiens.

Abstract

Ornaments such as beads are among the earliest signs of symbolic behavior among human ancestors. Their appearance signals important developments in both cognition and social relations. This paper describes and presents contextual information for 33 shell beads from Bizmoune Cave (southwest Morocco). Many of the beads come as deposits dating to ≥142 thousand years, making them the oldest shell beads yet recovered. They extend the dates for the first appearance of this behavior into the late Middle Pleistocene. The ages and ubiquity of beads in Middle Stone Age (MSA) sites in North Africa provide further evidence of the potential importance of these artifacts as signals of identity. The early and continued use of Tritia gibbosula and other material culture traits also suggest a remarkable degree of cultural continuity among early MSA Homo sapiens groups across North Africa.

INTRODUCTION

Symbolic artifacts and other behavioral indicators of hominin cognitive complexity appear quite early within Middle Stone Age (MSA) and Middle Paleolithic contexts in North Africa, South Africa, and southwest Asia. The most common and earliest material indicators of symbolic behavior are beads and other personal ornaments, frequently made from marine shells.

Some of the earliest evidence for use of marine shells in symbolic contexts comes from the eastern Mediterranean Levant. In Qafzeh Cave, layers dating to ca. 100 thousand years (ka) yielded Glycymeris insubrica shells with natural perforations (1). Clearer examples of shell beads were identified in Skhul Cave, on Mt. Carmel (2). The age of these artifacts could be between 100 and 135 ka (3). In South Africa, a large series of perforated Nassarius kraussianus shells from Blombos Cave (4) is dated to be between ca. 76 and 100 ka (5), while more varied assemblages of shell beads from the site of Sibudu date to somewhat later (6).

In North Africa, Tritia gibbosula shell beads occur in many MSA sites (7–10). A total of 33 perforated T. gibbosula shells have been recorded from a MSA/Aterian context at Grotte des Pigeons at Taforalt, with a most likely date of ~82.5 ka (7). Excavations at Contrebandiers Cave (8) identified a total of 151 shell beads in a context dated to ca. 115 ± 3 ka (9). At El Mnasra Cave, 234 T. gibbosula shells were collected from three MSA/Aterian layers (10). The age of this context was estimated to span the period ~107 to ~112 ka (11). At Ifri n’Ammar, in Eastern Morocco, single perforated specimens of Tritia and Columbella rustica were found in an MSA/Aterian context dated to 83 ka (12). Another single perforated Tritia shell was identified in Oued Djebbana, Algeria (

### 1. Facts given in the task
• The task is based on a Science Advances 2021 research article.  
 Reasoning: The research article is published in 2021 in Science Advances, which sets the context and publication date.  
• The article reports on shell beads made from a mollusk species.  
 Reasoning: The subject matter is centered on shell beads derived from a specific mollusk species.  
• The mollusk species is determined by its correspondence with the British Museum object that has the museum number 2012,5015.17.  
 Reasoning: This museum number is used to precisely identify the mollusk species used in the study.  
• The abstract of the article includes a statement that the beads are at least a certain number of thousands of years old.  
 Reasoning: This is a key piece of data to extract—the minimum age (in thousands of years) as mentioned in the abstract.  
• The final answer is expected to include three distinct parts:  
 - Task outcome (short version)  
 - Task outcome (extremely detailed version)  
 - Additional context (if relevant)  
 Reasoning: This structure is required to provide a comprehensive answer to the manager.

### 2. Facts to look up
• The full reference and access details for the Science Advances 2021 research article.  
 Reasoning: To locate the abstract, we need to know the exact article details possibly from a research database or the Science Advances website.  
 Potential sources: Science Advances website, academic databases (e.g., PubMed, Web of Science), or institutional access sites.  
• The exact abstract (or the relevant excerpt from it) of the article, particularly the portion that states the minimum age of the beads in thousands of years.  
 Reasoning: The abstract needs to be extracted in full (or at least the key excerpt) to answer the task accurately.  
 Potential sources: Article PDF, online journal website, or the article’s landing page on Science Advances.  
• Additional details about the British Museum object number 2012,5015.17, such as the mollusk species identification.  
 Reasoning: Confirming the species associated with this museum number may be necessary to ensure correct identification of the studied beads.  
 Potential sources: British Museum online collection database or official British Museum publications.  
• The numerical value (in thousands of years) mentioned in the abstract for the minimum age of the beads.  
 Reasoning: This specific number is a crucial part of the answer, and it must be extracted accurately from the abstract.

### 3. Facts to derive
• Derive the correct extraction of the key excerpt from the abstract that specifically states the minimum age ("at least [X] thousand years old") of the shell beads.  
 Reasoning: From the abstract, it is necessary to logically determine and isolate the statement regarding the beads' age.  
• Compute the relevance and context of the numerical value (e.g., ensuring it is expressed correctly and completely, such as "at least 45 thousand years old" if that is what is stated).  
 Reasoning: The task requires clarity about the temporal extent of the beads.
• Infer and compile the overall information into the final answer format with the specified three parts (short version, extremely detailed version, additional context).  
 Reasoning: Logical assembly of the pieces of information into a coherent final response that meets the task requirements.


```

Shell beads from Bizmoune Cave (Morocco) show the early appearance and continuity of symbolic behavior among early Homo sapiens.

Abstract

Ornaments such as beads are among the earliest signs of symbolic behavior among human ancestors. Their appearance signals important developments in both cognition and social relations. This paper describes and presents contextual information for 33 shell beads from Bizmoune Cave (southwest Morocco). Many of the beads come as deposits dating to ≥142 thousand years, making them the oldest shell beads yet recovered. They extend the dates for the first appearance of this behavior into the late Middle Pleistocene. The ages and ubiquity of beads in Middle Stone Age (MSA) sites in North Africa provide further evidence of the potential importance of these artifacts as signals of identity. The early and continued use of Tritia gibbosula and other material culture traits also suggest a remarkable degree of cultural continuity among early MSA Homo sapiens groups across North Africa.

INTRODUCTION

Symbolic artifacts and other behavioral indicators of hominin cognitive complexity appear quite early within Middle Stone Age (MSA) and Middle Paleolithic contexts in North Africa, South Africa, and southwest Asia. The most common and earliest material indicators of symbolic behavior are beads and other personal ornaments, frequently made from marine shells.

Some of the earliest evidence for use of marine shells in symbolic contexts comes from the eastern Mediterranean Levant. In Qafzeh Cave, layers dating to ca. 100 thousand years (ka) yielded Glycymeris insubrica shells with natural perforations (1). Clearer examples of shell beads were identified in Skhul Cave, on Mt. Carmel (2). The age of these artifacts could be between 100 and 135 ka (3). In South Africa, a large series of perforated Nassarius kraussianus shells from Blombos Cave (4) is dated to be between ca. 76 and 100 ka (5), while more varied assemblages of shell beads from the site of Sibudu date to somewhat later (6).

In North Africa, Tritia gibbosula shell beads occur in many MSA sites (7–10). A total of 33 perforated T. gibbosula shells have been recorded from a MSA/Aterian context at Grotte des Pigeons at Taforalt, with a most likely date of ~82.5 ka (7). Excavations at Contrebandiers Cave (8) identified a total of 151 shell beads in a context dated to ca. 115 ± 3 ka (9). At El Mnasra Cave, 234 T. gibbosula shells were collected from three MSA/Aterian layers (10). The age of this context was estimated to span the period ~107 to ~112 ka (11). At Ifri n’Ammar, in Eastern Morocco, single perforated specimens of Tritia and Columbella rustica were found in an MSA/Aterian context dated to 83 ka (12). Shell beads from Bizmoune Cave (Morocco) show the early appearance and continuity of symbolic behavior among early Homo sapiens.

Abstract

Ornaments such as beads are among the earliest signs of symbolic behavior among human ancestors. Their appearance signals important developments in both cognition and social relations. This paper describes and presents contextual information for 33 shell beads from Bizmoune Cave (southwest Morocco). Many of the beads come as deposits dating to ≥142 thousand years, making them the oldest shell beads yet recovered. They extend the dates for the first appearance of this behavior into the late Middle Pleistocene. The ages and ubiquity of beads in Middle Stone Age (MSA) sites in North Africa provide further evidence of the potential importance of these artifacts as signals of identity. The early and continued use of Tritia gibbosula and other material culture traits also suggest a remarkable degree of cultural continuity among early MSA Homo sapiens groups across North Africa.

INTRODUCTION

Symbolic artifacts and other behavioral indicators of hominin cognitive complexity appear quite early within Middle Stone Age (MSA) and Middle Paleolithic contexts in North Africa, South Africa, and southwest Asia. The most common and earliest material indicators of symbolic behavior are beads and other personal ornaments, frequently made from marine shells.

Some of the earliest evidence for use of marine shells in symbolic contexts comes from the eastern Mediterranean Levant. In Qafzeh Cave, layers dating to ca. 100 thousand years (ka) yielded Glycymeris insubrica shells with natural perforations (1). Clearer examples of shell beads were identified in Skhul Cave, on Mt. Carmel (2). The age of these artifacts could be between 100 and 135 ka (3). In South Africa, a large series of perforated Nassarius kraussianus shells from Blombos Cave (4) is dated to be between ca. 76 and 100 ka (5), while more varied assemblages of shell beads from the site of Sibudu date to somewhat later (6).

In North Africa, Tritia gibbosula shell beads occur in many MSA sites (7–10). A total of 33 perforated T. gibbosula shells have been recorded from a MSA/Aterian context at Grotte des Pigeons at Taforalt, with a most likely date of ~82.5 ka (7). Excavations at Contrebandiers Cave (8) identified a total of 151 shell beads in a context dated to ca. 115 ± 3 ka (9). At El Mnasra Cave, 234 T. gibbosula shells were collected from three MSA/Aterian layers (10). The age of this context was estimated to span the period ~107 to ~112 ka (11). At Ifri n’Ammar, in Eastern Morocco, single perforated specimens of Tritia and Columbella rustica were found in an MSA/Aterian context dated to 83 ka (12). Another single perforated Tritia shell was identified in Oued Djebbana, Algeria (

</div></section></section><section aria-label="Article content"><section class="body main-article-body"><section class="abstract" id="abstract1"><hr class="headless">
<p>Shell beads from Bizmoune Cave (Morocco) show the early appearance and continuity of symbolic behavior among early <em>Homo sapiens</em>.</p></section><section class="abstract" id="abstract2"><h2>Abstract</h2>
<p>Ornaments such as beads are among the earliest signs of symbolic behavior among human ancestors. Their appearance signals important developments in both cognition and social relations. This paper describes and presents contextual information for 33 shell beads from Bizmoune Cave (southwest Morocco). Many of the beads come as deposits dating to ≥142 thousand years, making them the oldest shell beads yet recovered. They extend the dates for the first appearance of this behavior into the late Middle Pleistocene. The ages and ubiquity of beads in Middle Stone Age (MSA) sites in North Africa provide further evidence of the potential importance of these artifacts as signals of identity. The early and continued use of <em>Tritia gibbosula</em> and other material culture traits also suggest a remarkable degree of cultural continuity among early MSA <em>Homo sapiens</em> groups across North Africa.</p></section><section id="sec1"><h2 class="pmc_sec_title">INTRODUCTION</h2>
<p>Symbolic artifacts and other behavioral indicators of hominin cognitive complexity appear quite early within Middle Stone Age (MSA) and Middle Paleolithic contexts in North Africa, South Africa, and southwest Asia. The most common and earliest material indicators of symbolic behavior are beads and other personal ornaments, frequently made from marine shells.</p>
<p>Some of the earliest evidence for use of marine shells in symbolic contexts comes from the eastern Mediterranean Levant. In Qafzeh Cave, layers dating to ca. 100 thousand years (ka) yielded <em>Glycymeris insubrica</em> shells with natural perforations (<a href="#R1" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R1"><em>1</em></a>). Clearer examples of shell beads were identified in Skhul Cave, on Mt. Carmel (<a href="#R2" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R2"><em>2</em></a>). The age of these artifacts could be between 100 and 135 ka (<a href="#R3" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R3"><em>3</em></a>). In South Africa, a large series of perforated <em>Nassarius kraussianus</em> shells from Blombos Cave (<a href="#R4" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R4"><em>4</em></a>) is dated to be between ca. 76 and 100 ka (<a href="#R5" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R5"><em>5</em></a>), while more varied assemblages of shell beads from the site of Sibudu date to somewhat later (<a href="#R6" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R6"><em>6</em></a>).</p>
<p>In North Africa, <em>Tritia gibbosula</em> shell beads occur in many MSA sites (<a href="#R7" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R7"><em>7</em></a>–<a href="#R10" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R10"><em>10</em></a>). A total of 33 perforated <em>T. gibbosula</em> shells have been recorded from a MSA/Aterian context at Grotte des Pigeons at Taforalt, with a most likely date of ~82.5 ka (<a href="#R7" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R7"><em>7</em></a>). Excavations at Contrebandiers Cave (<a href="#R8" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R8"><em>8</em></a>) identified a total of 151 shell beads in a context dated to ca. 115 ± 3 ka (<a href="#R9" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R9"><em>9</em></a>). At El Mnasra Cave, 234 <em>T. gibbosula</em> shells were collected from three MSA/Aterian layers (<a href="#R10" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R10"><em>10</em></a>). The age of this context was estimated to span the period ~107 to ~112 ka (<a href="#R11" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R11"><em>11</em></a>). At Ifri n’Ammar, in Eastern Morocco, single perforated specimens of <em>Tritia</em> and <em>Columbella rustica</em> were found in an MSA/Aterian context dated to 83 ka (<a href="#R12" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R12"><em>12</em></a>). Another single perforated <em>Tritia</em> shell was identified in Oued Djebbana, Algeria (<a href="#R13" class="usa-link""}]}, {"role": "user", "content": [{"type": "text", "text": "Earlier we've built a list of facts.

Shell beads from Bizmoune Cave (Morocco) show the early appearance and continuity of symbolic behavior among early Homo sapiens.

Abstract

Ornaments such as beads are among the earliest signs of symbolic behavior among human ancestors. Their appearance signals important developments in both cognition and social relations. This paper describes and presents contextual information for 33 shell beads from Bizmoune Cave (southwest Morocco). Many of the beads come as deposits dating to ≥142 thousand years, making them the oldest shell beads yet recovered. They extend the dates for the first appearance of this behavior into the late Middle Pleistocene. The ages and ubiquity of beads in Middle Stone Age (MSA) sites in North Africa provide further evidence of the potential importance of these artifacts as signals of identity. The early and continued use of Tritia gibbosula and other material culture traits also suggest a remarkable degree of cultural continuity among early MSA Homo sapiens groups across North Africa.

INTRODUCTION

Symbolic artifacts and other behavioral indicators of hominin cognitive complexity appear quite early within Middle Stone Age (MSA) and Middle Paleolithic contexts in North Africa, South Africa, and southwest Asia. The most common and earliest material indicators of symbolic behavior are beads and other personal ornaments, frequently made from marine shells.

Some of the earliest evidence for use of marine shells in symbolic contexts comes from the eastern Mediterranean Levant. In Qafzeh Cave, layers dating to ca. 100 thousand years (ka) yielded Glycymeris insubrica shells with natural perforations (1). Clearer examples of shell beads were identified in Skhul Cave, on Mt. Carmel (2). The age of these artifacts could be between 100 and 135 ka (3). In South Africa, a large series of perforated Nassarius kraussianus shells from Blombos Cave (4) is dated to be between ca. 76 and 100 ka (5), while more varied assemblages of shell beads from the site of Sibudu date to somewhat later (6).

In North Africa, Tritia gibbosula shell beads occur in many MSA sites (7–10). A total of 33 perforated T. gibbosula shells have been recorded from a MSA/Aterian context at Grotte des Pigeons at Taforalt, with a most likely date of ~82.5 ka (7). Excavations at Contrebandiers Cave (8) identified a total of 151 shell beads in a context dated to ca. 115 ± 3 ka (9). At El Mnasra Cave, 234 T. gibbosula shells were collected from three MSA/Aterian layers (10). The age of this context was estimated to span the period ~107 to ~112 ka (11). At Ifri n’Ammar, in Eastern Morocco, single perforated specimens of Tritia and Columbella rustica were found in an MSA/Aterian context dated to 83 ka (12). Another single perforated Tritia shell was identified in Oued Djebbana, Algeria (

</div></section></section><section aria-label="Article content"><section class="body main-article-body"><section class="abstract" id="abstract1"><hr class="headless">
<p>Shell beads from Bizmoune Cave (Morocco) show the early appearance and continuity of symbolic behavior among early <em>Homo sapiens</em>.</p></section><section class="abstract" id="abstract2"><h2>Abstract</h2>
<p>Ornaments such as beads are among the earliest signs of symbolic behavior among human ancestors. Their appearance signals important developments in both cognition and social relations. This paper describes and presents contextual information for 33 shell beads from Bizmoune Cave (southwest Morocco). Many of the beads come as deposits dating to ≥142 thousand years, making them the oldest shell beads yet recovered. They extend the dates for the first appearance of this behavior into the late Middle Pleistocene. The ages and ubiquity of beads in Middle Stone Age (MSA) sites in North Africa provide further evidence of the potential importance of these artifacts as signals of identity. The early and continued use of <em>Tritia gibbosula</em> and other material culture traits also suggest a remarkable degree of cultural continuity among early MSA <em>Homo sapiens</em> groups across North Africa.</p></section><section id="sec1"><h2 class="pmc_sec_title">INTRODUCTION</h2>
<p>Symbolic artifacts and other behavioral indicators of hominin cognitive complexity appear quite early within Middle Stone Age (MSA) and Middle Paleolithic contexts in North Africa, South Africa, and southwest Asia. The most common and earliest material indicators of symbolic behavior are beads and other personal ornaments, frequently made from marine shells.</p>
<p>Some of the earliest evidence for use of marine shells in symbolic contexts comes from the eastern Mediterranean Levant. In Qafzeh Cave, layers dating to ca. 100 thousand years (ka) yielded <em>Glycymeris insubrica</em> shells with natural perforations (<a href="#R1" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R1"><em>1</em></a>). Clearer examples of shell beads were identified in Skhul Cave, on Mt. Carmel (<a href="#R2" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R2"><em>2</em></a>). The age of these artifacts could be between 100 and 135 ka (<a href="#R3" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R3"><em>3</em></a>). In South Africa, a large series of perforated <em>Nassarius kraussianus</em> shells from Blombos Cave (<a href="#R4" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R4"><em>4</em></a>) is dated to be between ca. 76 and 100 ka (<a href="#R5" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R5"><em>5</em></a>), while more varied assemblages of shell beads from the site of Sibudu date to somewhat later (<a href="#R6" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R6"><em>6</em></a>).</p>
<p>In North Africa, <em>Tritia gibbosula</em> shell beads occur in many MSA sites (<a href="#R7" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R7"><em>7</em></a>–<a href="#R10" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R10"><em>10</em></a>). A total of 33 perforated <em>T. gibbosula</em> shells have been recorded from a MSA/Aterian context at Grotte des Pigeons at Taforalt, with a most likely date of ~82.5 ka (<a href="#R7" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R7"><em>7</em></a>). Excavations at Contrebandiers Cave (<a href="#R8" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R8"><em>8</em></a>) identified a total of 151 shell beads in a context dated to ca. 115 ± 3 ka (<a href="#R9" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R9"><em>9</em></a>). At El Mnasra Cave, 234 <em>T. gibbosula</em> shells were collected from three MSA/Aterian layers (<a href="#R10" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R10"><em>10</em></a>). The age of this context was estimated to span the period ~107 to ~112 ka (<a href="#R11" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R11"><em>11</em></a>). At Ifri n’Ammar, in Eastern Morocco, single perforated specimens of <em>Tritia</em> and <em>Columbella rustica</em> were found in an MSA/Aterian context dated to 83 ka (<a href="#R12" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R12"><em>12</em></a>). Another single perforated <em>Tritia</em> shell was identified in Oued Djebbana, Algeria (<a href="#R13" class="usa-link""}]}, {"role": "user", "content": [{"type": "text", "text": "You're still working towards solving this task:

Shell beads from Bizmoune Cave (Morocco) show the early appearance and continuity of symbolic behavior among early Homo sapiens.

Abstract

Ornaments such as beads are among the earliest signs of symbolic behavior among human ancestors. Their appearance signals important developments in both cognition and social relations. This paper describes and presents contextual information for 33 shell beads from Bizmoune Cave (southwest Morocco). Many of the beads come as deposits dating to ≥142 thousand years, making them the oldest shell beads yet recovered. They extend the dates for the first appearance of this behavior into the late Middle Pleistocene. The ages and ubiquity of beads in Middle Stone Age (MSA) sites in North Africa provide further evidence of the potential importance of these artifacts as signals of identity. The early and continued use of Tritia gibbosula and other material culture traits also suggest a remarkable degree of cultural continuity among early MSA Homo sapiens groups across North Africa.

INTRODUCTION

Symbolic artifacts and other behavioral indicators of hominin cognitive complexity appear quite early within Middle Stone Age (MSA) and Middle Paleolithic contexts in North Africa, South Africa, and southwest Asia. The most common and earliest material indicators of symbolic behavior are beads and other personal ornaments, frequently made from marine shells.

Some of the earliest evidence for use of marine shells in symbolic contexts comes from the eastern Mediterranean Levant. In Qafzeh Cave, layers dating to ca. 100 thousand years (ka) yielded Glycymeris insubrica shells with natural perforations (1). Clearer examples of shell beads were identified in Skhul Cave, on Mt. Carmel (2). The age of these artifacts could be between 100 and 135 ka (3). In South Africa, a large series of perforated Nassarius kraussianus shells from Blombos Cave (4) is dated to be between ca. 76 and 100 ka (5), while more varied assemblages of shell beads from the site of Sibudu date to somewhat later (6).

In North Africa, Tritia gibbosula shell beads occur in many MSA sites (7–10). A total of 33 perforated T. gibbosula shells have been recorded from a MSA/Aterian context at Grotte des Pigeons at Taforalt, with a most likely date of ~82.5 ka (7). Excavations at Contrebandiers Cave (8) identified a total of 151 shell beads in a context dated to ca. 115 ± 3 ka (9). At El Mnasra Cave, 234 T. gibbosula shells were collected from three MSA/Aterian layers (10). The age of this context was estimated to span the period ~107 to ~112 ka (11). At Ifri n’Ammar, in Eastern Morocco, single perforated specimens of Tritia and Columbella rustica were found in an MSA/Aterian context dated to 83 ka (12). Another single perforated Tritia shell was identified in Oued Djebbana, Algeria (

</div></section></section><section aria-label="Article content"><section class="body main-article-body"><section class="abstract" id="abstract1"><hr class="headless">
<p>Shell beads from Bizmoune Cave (Morocco) show the early appearance and continuity of symbolic behavior among early <em>Homo sapiens</em>.</p></section><section class="abstract" id="abstract2"><h2>Abstract</h2>
<p>Ornaments such as beads are among the earliest signs of symbolic behavior among human ancestors. Their appearance signals important developments in both cognition and social relations. This paper describes and presents contextual information for 33 shell beads from Bizmoune Cave (southwest Morocco). Many of the beads come as deposits dating to ≥142 thousand years, making them the oldest shell beads yet recovered. They extend the dates for the first appearance of this behavior into the late Middle Pleistocene. The ages and ubiquity of beads in Middle Stone Age (MSA) sites in North Africa provide further evidence of the potential importance of these artifacts as signals of identity. The early and continued use of <em>Tritia gibbosula</em> and other material culture traits also suggest a remarkable degree of cultural continuity among early MSA <em>Homo sapiens</em> groups across North Africa.</p></section><section id="sec1"><h2 class="pmc_sec_title">INTRODUCTION</h2>
<p>Symbolic artifacts and other behavioral indicators of hominin cognitive complexity appear quite early within Middle Stone Age (MSA) and Middle Paleolithic contexts in North Africa, South Africa, and southwest Asia. The most common and earliest material indicators of symbolic behavior are beads and other personal ornaments, frequently made from marine shells.</p>
<p>Some of the earliest evidence for use of marine shells in symbolic contexts comes from the eastern Mediterranean Levant. In Qafzeh Cave, layers dating to ca. 100 thousand years (ka) yielded <em>Glycymeris insubrica</em> shells with natural perforations (<a href="#R1" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R1"><em>1</em></a>). Clearer examples of shell beads were identified in Skhul Cave, on Mt. Carmel (<a href="#R2" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R2"><em>2</em></a>). The age of these artifacts could be between 100 and 135 ka (<a href="#R3" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R3"><em>3</em></a>). In South Africa, a large series of perforated <em>Nassarius kraussianus</em> shells from Blombos Cave (<a href="#R4" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R4"><em>4</em></a>) is dated to be between ca. 76 and 100 ka (<a href="#R5" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R5"><em>5</em></a>), while more varied assemblages of shell beads from the site of Sibudu date to somewhat later (<a href="#R6" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R6"><em>6</em></a>).</p>
<p>In North Africa, <em>Tritia gibbosula</em> shell beads occur in many MSA sites (<a href="#R7" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R7"><em>7</em></a>–<a href="#R10" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R10"><em>10</em></a>). A total of 33 perforated <em>T. gibbosula</em> shells have been recorded from a MSA/Aterian context at Grotte des Pigeons at Taforalt, with a most likely date of ~82.5 ka (<a href="#R7" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R7"><em>7</em></a>). Excavations at Contrebandiers Cave (<a href="#R8" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R8"><em>8</em></a>) identified a total of 151 shell beads in a context dated to ca. 115 ± 3 ka (<a href="#R9" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R9"><em>9</em></a>). At El Mnasra Cave, 234 <em>T. gibbosula</em> shells were collected from three MSA/Aterian layers (<a href="#R10" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R10"><em>10</em></a>). The age of this context was estimated to span the period ~107 to ~112 ka (<a href="#R11" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R11"><em>11</em></a>). At Ifri n’Ammar, in Eastern Morocco, single perforated specimens of <em>Tritia</em> and <em>Columbella rustica</em> were found in an MSA/Aterian context dated to 83 ka (<a href="#R12" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R12"><em>12</em></a>). Another single perforated <em>Tritia</em> shell was identified in Oued Djebbana, Algeria (<a href="#R13" class="usa-link""}]}, {"role": "assistant", "content": [{"type": "text", "text": "[FACTS LIST]:

Shell beads from Bizmoune Cave (Morocco) show the early appearance and continuity of symbolic behavior among early Homo sapiens.

Abstract

Ornaments such as beads are among the earliest signs of symbolic behavior among human ancestors. Their appearance signals important developments in both cognition and social relations. This paper describes and presents contextual information for 33 shell beads from Bizmoune Cave (southwest Morocco). Many of the beads come as deposits dating to ≥142 thousand years, making them the oldest shell beads yet recovered. They extend the dates for the first appearance of this behavior into the late Middle Pleistocene. The ages and ubiquity of beads in Middle Stone Age (MSA) sites in North Africa provide further evidence of the potential importance of these artifacts as signals of identity. The early and continued use of Tritia gibbosula and other material culture traits also suggest a remarkable degree of cultural continuity among early MSA Homo sapiens groups across North Africa.

INTRODUCTION

Symbolic artifacts and other behavioral indicators of hominin cognitive complexity appear quite early within Middle Stone Age (MSA) and Middle Paleolithic contexts in North Africa, South Africa, and southwest Asia. The most common and earliest material indicators of symbolic behavior are beads and other personal ornaments, frequently made from marine shells.

Some of the earliest evidence for use of marine shells in symbolic contexts comes from the eastern Mediterranean Levant. In Qafzeh Cave, layers dating to ca. 100 thousand years (ka) yielded Glycymeris insubrica shells with natural perforations (1). Clearer examples of shell beads were identified in Skhul Cave, on Mt. Carmel (2). The age of these artifacts could be between 100 and 135 ka (3). In South Africa, a large series of perforated Nassarius kraussianus shells from Blombos Cave (4) is dated to be between ca. 76 and 100 ka (5), while more varied assemblages of shell beads from the site of Sibudu date to somewhat later (6).

In North Africa, Tritia gibbosula shell beads occur in many MSA sites (7–10). A total of 33 perforated T. gibbosula shells have been recorded from a MSA/Aterian context at Grotte des Pigeons at Taforalt, with a most likely date of ~82.5 ka (7). Excavations at Contrebandiers Cave (8) identified a total of 151 shell beads in a context dated to ca. 115 ± 3 ka (9). At El Mnasra Cave, 234 T. gibbosula shells were collected from three MSA/Aterian layers (10). The age of this context was estimated to span the period ~107 to ~112 ka (11). At Ifri n’Ammar, in Eastern Morocco, single perforated specimens of Tritia and Columbella rustica were found in an MSA/Aterian context dated to 83 ka (12). Another single perforated Tritia shell was identified in Oued Djebbana, Algeria (

The most common and earliest material indicators of symbolic behavior are beads and other personal ornaments, frequently made from marine shells.</p>\n<p>Some of the earliest evidence for use of marine shells in symbolic contexts comes from the eastern Mediterranean Levant. In Qafzeh Cave, layers dating to ca. 100 thousand years (ka) yielded <em>Glycymeris insubrica</em> shells with natural perforations (<a href="#R1" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R1"><em>1</em></a>). A total of 33 perforated <em>T. gibbosula</em> shells have been recorded from a MSA/Aterian context at Grotte des Pigeons at Taforalt, with a most likely date of ~82.5 ka (<a href="#R7" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R7"><em>7</em></a>). The age of this context was estimated to span the period ~107 to ~112 ka (<a href="#R11" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R11"><em>11</em></a>). Shell beads from Bizmoune Cave (Morocco) show the early appearance and continuity of symbolic behavior among early Homo sapiens.

Abstract

Ornaments such as beads are among the earliest signs of symbolic behavior among human ancestors. Their appearance signals important developments in both cognition and social relations. This paper describes and presents contextual information for 33 shell beads from Bizmoune Cave (southwest Morocco). Many of the beads come as deposits dating to ≥142 thousand years, making them the oldest shell beads yet recovered. They extend the dates for the first appearance of this behavior into the late Middle Pleistocene. The ages and ubiquity of beads in Middle Stone Age (MSA) sites in North Africa provide further evidence of the potential importance of these artifacts as signals of identity. The early and continued use of Tritia gibbosula and other material culture traits also suggest a remarkable degree of cultural continuity among early MSA Homo sapiens groups across North Africa.

INTRODUCTION

Symbolic artifacts and other behavioral indicators of hominin cognitive complexity appear quite early within Middle Stone Age (MSA) and Middle Paleolithic contexts in North Africa, South Africa, and southwest Asia. The most common and earliest material indicators of symbolic behavior are beads and other personal ornaments, frequently made from marine shells.

Some of the earliest evidence for use of marine shells in symbolic contexts comes from the eastern Mediterranean Levant. In Qafzeh Cave, layers dating to ca. 100 thousand years (ka) yielded Glycymeris insubrica shells with natural perforations (1). Clearer examples of shell beads were identified in Skhul Cave, on Mt. Carmel (2). The age of these artifacts could be between 100 and 135 ka (3). In South Africa, a large series of perforated Nassarius kraussianus shells from Blombos Cave (4) is dated to be between ca. 76 and 100 ka (5), while more varied assemblages of shell beads from the site of Sibudu date to somewhat later (6).

In North Africa, Tritia gibbosula shell beads occur in many MSA sites (7–10). A total of 33 perforated T. gibbosula shells have been recorded from a MSA/Aterian context at Grotte des Pigeons at Taforalt, with a most likely date of ~82.5 ka (7). Excavations at Contrebandiers Cave (8) identified a total of 151 shell beads in a context dated to ca. 115 ± 3 ka (9). At El Mnasra Cave, 234 T. gibbosula shells were collected from three MSA/Aterian layers (10). The age of this context was estimated to span the period ~107 to ~112 ka (11). At Ifri n’Ammar, in Eastern Morocco, single perforated specimens of Tritia and Columbella rustica were found in an MSA/Aterian context dated to 83 ka (12). Another single perforated Tritia shell was identified in Oued Djebbana, Algeria (

Their appearance signals important developments in both cognition and social relations. This paper describes and presents contextual information for 33 shell beads from Bizmoune Cave (southwest Morocco). Many of the beads come as deposits dating to ≥142 thousand years, making them the oldest shell beads yet recovered. They extend the dates for the first appearance of this behavior into the late Middle Pleistocene. The ages and ubiquity of beads in Middle Stone Age (MSA) sites in North Africa provide further evidence of the potential importance of these artifacts as signals of identity. The early and continued use of <em>Tritia gibbosula</em> and other material culture traits also suggest a remarkable degree of cultural continuity among early MSA <em>Homo sapiens</em> groups across North Africa.</p></section><section id="sec1"><h2 class="pmc_sec_title">INTRODUCTION</h2>\n<p>Symbolic artifacts and other behavioral indicators of hominin cognitive complexity appear quite early within Middle Stone Age (MSA) and Middle Paleolithic contexts in North Africa, South Africa, and southwest Asia. The most common and earliest material indicators of symbolic behavior are beads and other personal ornaments, frequently made from marine shells.</p>\n<p>Some of the earliest evidence for use of marine shells in symbolic contexts comes from the eastern Mediterranean Levant. In Qafzeh Cave, layers dating to ca. 100 thousand years (ka) yielded <em>Glycymeris insubrica</em> shells with natural perforations (<a href="#R1" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R1"><em>1</em></a>). Clearer examples of shell beads were identified in Skhul Cave, on Mt. Carmel (<a href="#R2" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R2"><em>2</em></a>). The age of these artifacts could be between 100 and 135 ka (<a href="#R3" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R3"><em>3</em></a>). In South Africa, a large series of perforated <em>Nassarius kraussianus</em> shells from Blombos Cave (<a href="#R4" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R4"><em>4</em></a>) is dated to be between ca. 76 and 100 ka (<a href="#R5" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R5"><em>5</em></a>), while more varied assemblages of shell beads from the site of Sibudu date to somewhat later (<a href="#R6" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R6"><em>6</em></a>).</p>\n<p>In North Africa, <em>Tritia gibbosula</em> shell beads occur in many MSA sites (<a href="#R7" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R7"><em>7</em></a>–<a href="#R10" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R10"><em>10</em></a>). A total of 33 perforated <em>T. gibbosula</em> shells have been recorded from a MSA/Aterian context at Grotte des Pigeons at Taforalt, with a most likely date of ~82.5 ka (<a href="#R7" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R7"><em>7</em></a>). At El Mnasra Cave, 234 <em>T. gibbosula</em> shells were collected from three MSA/Aterian layers (<a href="#R10" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R10"><em>10</em></a>). The age of this context was estimated to span the period ~107 to ~112 ka (<a href="#R11" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R11"><em>11</em></a>). At Ifri n’Ammar, in Eastern Morocco, single perforated specimens of <em>Tritia</em> and <em>Columbella rustica</em> were found in an MSA/Aterian context dated to 83 ka (<a href="#R12" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="R12"><em>12</em></a>). Shell beads from Bizmoune Cave (Morocco) show the early appearance and continuity of symbolic behavior among early Homo sapiens.

Abstract

Ornaments such as beads are among the earliest signs of symbolic behavior among human ancestors. Their appearance signals important developments in both cognition and social relations. This paper describes and presents contextual information for 33 shell beads from Bizmoune Cave (southwest Morocco). Many of the beads come as deposits dating to ≥142 thousand years, making them the oldest shell beads yet recovered. They extend the dates for the first appearance of this behavior into the late Middle Pleistocene. The ages and ubiquity of beads in Middle Stone Age (MSA) sites in North Africa provide further evidence of the potential importance of these artifacts as signals of identity. The early and continued use of Tritia gibbosula and other material culture traits also suggest a remarkable degree of cultural continuity among early MSA Homo sapiens groups across North Africa.

INTRODUCTION

Symbolic artifacts and other behavioral indicators of hominin cognitive complexity appear quite early within Middle Stone Age (MSA) and Middle Paleolithic contexts in North Africa, South Africa, and southwest Asia. The most common and earliest material indicators of symbolic behavior are beads and other personal ornaments, frequently made from marine shells.

Some of the earliest evidence for use of marine shells in symbolic contexts comes from the eastern Mediterranean Levant. In Qafzeh Cave, layers dating to ca. 100 thousand years (ka) yielded Glycymeris insubrica shells with natural perforations (1). Clearer examples of shell beads were identified in Skhul Cave, on Mt. Carmel (2). The age of these artifacts could be between 100 and 135 ka (3). In South Africa, a large series of perforated Nassarius kraussianus shells from Blombos Cave (4) is dated to be between ca. 76 and 100 ka (5), while more varied assemblages of shell beads from the site of Sibudu date to somewhat later (6).

In North Africa, Tritia gibbosula shell beads occur in many MSA sites (7–10). A total of 33 perforated T. gibbosula shells have been recorded from a MSA/Aterian context at Grotte des Pigeons at Taforalt, with a most likely date of ~82.5 ka (7). Excavations at Contrebandiers Cave (8) identified a total of 151 shell beads in a context dated to ca. 115 ± 3 ka (9). At El Mnasra Cave, 234 T. gibbosula shells were collected from three MSA/Aterian layers (10). The age of this context was estimated to span the period ~107 to ~112 ka (11). At Ifri n’Ammar, in Eastern Morocco, single perforated specimens of Tritia and Columbella rustica were found in an MSA/Aterian context dated to 83 ka (12). Another single perforated Tritia shell was identified in Oued Djebbana, Algeria (

Shell beads from Bizmoune Cave (Morocco) show the early appearance and continuity of symbolic behavior among early Homo sapiens.

Abstract

\n

Ornaments such as beads are among the earliest signs of symbolic behavior among human ancestors. Their appearance signals important developments in both cognition and social relations. This paper describes and presents contextual information for 33 shell beads from Bizmoune Cave (southwest Morocco). Many of the beads come as deposits dating to ≥142 thousand years, making them the oldest shell beads yet recovered. They extend the dates for the first appearance of this behavior into the late Middle Pleistocene. The ages and ubiquity of beads in Middle Stone Age (MSA) sites in North Africa provide further evidence of the potential importance of these artifacts as signals of identity. The early and continued use of Tritia gibbosula and other material culture traits also suggest a remarkable degree of cultural continuity among early MSA Homo sapiens groups across North Africa.

INTRODUCTION

\n

Symbolic artifacts and other behavioral indicators of hominin cognitive complexity appear quite early within Middle Stone Age (MSA) and Middle Paleolithic contexts in North Africa, South Africa, and southwest Asia. The most common and earliest material indicators of symbolic behavior are beads and other personal ornaments, frequently made from marine shells.

\n

Some of the earliest evidence for use of marine shells in symbolic contexts comes from the eastern Mediterranean Levant. In Qafzeh Cave, layers dating to ca. 100 thousand years (ka) yielded Glycymeris insubrica shells with natural perforations (1). Clearer examples of shell beads were identified in Skhul Cave, on Mt. Carmel (2). The age of these artifacts could be between 100 and 135 ka (3). In South Africa, a large series of perforated Nassarius kraussianus shells from Blombos Cave (4) is dated to be between ca. 76 and 100 ka (5), while more varied assemblages of shell beads from the site of Sibudu date to somewhat later (6).

\n

In North Africa, Tritia gibbosula shell beads occur in many MSA sites (7–10). A total of 33 perforated T. gibbosula shells have been recorded from a MSA/Aterian context at Grotte des Pigeons at Taforalt, with a most likely date of ~82.5 ka (7). Excavations at Contrebandiers Cave (8) identified a total of 151 shell beads in a context dated to ca. 115 ± 3 ka (9). At El Mnasra Cave, 234 T. gibbosula shells were collected from three MSA/Aterian layers (10). The age of this context was estimated to span the period ~107 to ~112 ka (11). At Ifri n’Ammar, in Eastern Morocco, single perforated specimens of Tritia and Columbella rustica were found in an MSA/Aterian context dated to 83 ka (12). Shell beads from Bizmoune Cave (Morocco) show the early appearance and continuity of symbolic behavior among early Homo sapiens.

Abstract

Ornaments such as beads are among the earliest signs of symbolic behavior among human ancestors. Their appearance signals important developments in both cognition and social relations. This paper describes and presents contextual information for 33 shell beads from Bizmoune Cave (southwest Morocco). Many of the beads come as deposits dating to ≥142 thousand years, making them the oldest shell beads yet recovered. They extend the dates for the first appearance of this behavior into the late Middle Pleistocene. The ages and ubiquity of beads in Middle Stone Age (MSA) sites in North Africa provide further evidence of the potential importance of these artifacts as signals of identity. The early and continued use of Tritia gibbosula and other material culture traits also suggest a remarkable degree of cultural continuity among early MSA Homo sapiens groups across North Africa.

INTRODUCTION

Symbolic artifacts and other behavioral indicators of hominin cognitive complexity appear quite early within Middle Stone Age (MSA) and Middle Paleolithic contexts in North Africa, South Africa, and southwest Asia. The most common and earliest material indicators of symbolic behavior are beads and other personal ornaments, frequently made from marine shells.

Some of the earliest evidence for use of marine shells in symbolic contexts comes from the eastern Mediterranean Levant. In Qafzeh Cave, layers dating to ca. 100 thousand years (ka) yielded Glycymeris insubrica shells with natural perforations (1). Clearer examples of shell beads were identified in Skhul Cave, on Mt. Carmel (2). The age of these artifacts could be between 100 and 135 ka (3). In South Africa, a large series of perforated Nassarius kraussianus shells from Blombos Cave (4) is dated to be between ca. 76 and 100 ka (5), while more varied assemblages of shell beads from the site of Sibudu date to somewhat later (6).

In North Africa, Tritia gibbosula shell beads occur in many MSA sites (7–10). A total of 33 perforated T. gibbosula shells have been recorded from a MSA/Aterian context at Grotte des Pigeons at Taforalt, with a most likely date of ~82.5 ka (7). Excavations at Contrebandiers Cave (8) identified a total of 151 shell beads in a context dated to ca. 115 ± 3 ka (9). At El Mnasra Cave, 234 T. gibbosula shells were collected from three MSA/Aterian layers (10). The age of this context was estimated to span the period ~107 to ~112 ka (11). At Ifri n’Ammar, in Eastern Morocco, single perforated specimens of Tritia and Columbella rustica were found in an MSA/Aterian context dated to 83 ka (12). Another single perforated Tritia shell was identified in Oued Djebbana, Algeria (
